awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Enabling Quantum Leap: Towards Room Temperature Quantum Logic with Topological Exciton Condensates
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: Quantum computers promise the next great technology leap. At the heart of a quantum computer are material implementations of quantum bits - qubits - which in the present form are highly sensitive to the environment and are typically only achieved at very low temperatures. This project aims to discover a new type of material that may enable room-temperature quantum computing. The new method is based on electrons and their associated vacancies, also known as holes, in a solid material. When an electron lingers close to a hole, the electrical attraction between the pair leads to the formation of a quantum particle known as an exciton. This project explores the utilization of excitons as qubits for enabling quantum logic devices. Recent studies suggest that excitons may be formed above room temperature in a new type of material known as a topological insulator. The principal investigators use a variety of experimental techniques to understand the nature of excitons in topological insulators, and improve the critical temperature for achieving them, so that they may be sustained at room temperature. This project educates and trains undergraduate and graduate students in the important and rapidly advancing research area of quantum computation, and offers outreach activities targeting K-12 students from underrepresented minority groups.

Technical Description: Topological exciton condensation is a fundamentally new concept which may open an unexplored and exciting research area. Our recent experimental studies of three-dimensional topological insulators have revealed unusual non-local photocurrent at liquid nitrogen temperature, indicating a superfluid-like topological exciton condensate. This project builds on these exciting preliminary results and aims to obtain fundamental understanding of topological exciton condensates. Experiments to unambiguously distinguish the free Fermion and exciton mechanisms by conducting electric field dependent photocurrent mapping are performed. Spatially resolved angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (micro-ARPES) supports this effort by characterizing the occupied single-particle spectrum of materials platforms where signatures of an excitonic condensate are observed.  Ultrafast spectroscopy is carried out to measure exciton lifetime and velocity. The exciton induced spin polarization is explored using Kerr rotation. An even higher onset temperature for exciton condensation is achieved in thinner and more intrinsic samples and other low dimensional topological materials beyond Bi2Se3. The topological exciton condensate, a high-temperature macroscopic quantum state with long coherence lengths and unique spin texture, has a truly promising potential to be implemented in room-temperature quantum computers.

por.por_cntn:
Excitons, electron-hole pairs bound by Coulomb interaction, have integer spin and may form a unique quantum state that provides a novel basis for quantum computation. Because of the strong electrical interaction between electrons and holes, exciton-based quantum states may be realized at relatively high temperature, potentially even at room temperature. This can be very attractive to build practical quantum computers. A newly discovered category of materials, called topological insulators, can be an excellent flatform for realizing such a quantum state. The principal investigators' research groups have demonstrated unusual long-distance transport of photogenerated charge carriers in topological insulators, which suggests the formation of such a quantum state.

Using this NSF grant, the principal investigators' research groups have synthesized the nanostructures composed of topological materials and fabricated nanodevices. Comprehensive experiments, including spatially, energetically, and temporally resolved photocurrent have been carried out in these devices at various temperatures. Doping effects on the photogenerated charge carrier transport and lifetime have been determined.  Helicity-dependent photocurrent mapping has been performed to garner important information in spin and charge interaction as well. All these results have greatly deepened the understanding of transport of photogenerated charge carriers in topological insulators and are consistent with the hypothesis of exciton condensation in topological insulators, though further work is needed to fully confirm.

This project also educates and trains undergraduate and graduate students in the rapidly advancing research area of quantum and spintronic devices. Five graduate students and several undergraduate students (including 2 NSF-REU and 1 MURRPS students) have worked on this project. Yasen Hou has graduated and currently works as a postdoc at MIT. Luke McClintock has received the UC-National Lab In-Residence Graduate Fellowship and the DOE Office of Science Graduate Student Research (SCGSR) award. The project has resulted in 10 publications including 2 Nature Communications, 1 ACS Nano, 2 Physical Review B, and 12 invited talks including APS March meeting, RIKEN-Berkeley workshop, Nanjing Conference on quantum materials, annual Molecular Foundry user meeting, and Advanced Light Source (ALS) user meeting.
